Notes on pdf format
The pdf format conserves layout rather than structured content. It is widely adopted and well-suited for dissemination, but has limitations for archival and digital preservation. This primarily refers to automated metadata extraction (even basic bibliographic elements) with machine-based technology. As already mentioned, pdf also isn’t suitable for tabulated numeric data because these data cannot be (readily) re-used.
 
The purpose of this essay is to describe the pdf format and its limitations, and to offer (partial) solutions for archival purposes.
 
General description of pdf format
PDF has become a de facto format for exchange of print-oriented documents, ensuring robust visual presentation across a variety of operating systems and platforms and preserving the author’s intent in finalized form. It was partly designed for the Internet and is thus well-suited for documents available on-line.
 
While proprietary in origin, it is now part of a family of ISO standards. In 2008, control of specifications was passed to an ISO committee of voluntary industry experts (including, but not limited to Adobe Inc.). Adobe Reader is freely available (no definite guarantee that this will always be the case), third parties can develop PDF tools.
 
PDF files most commonly contain text, graphic paths and/or images and may also incorporate e.g. video/audio and hyperlinks to external content. They become incompatible with source files: The initial image format is not conserved, and it is difficult to convert pdf files back into Microsoft Word – paragraphs, formatting, line breaks etc. are not preserved.
 
PDF/A for archival purposes and Tagged PDF
The PDF/A format is designed to be self-contained without external dependencies: Fonts have to be embedded (rather than linked), device-independent color information has to be provided. Forbidden content includes audio, video, JavaScript and executable file launches. However, annotations such as hyperlinks are allowed – while not necessarily permanent. PDF/A preserves additional information in documents beyond what is needed for printing.
 
Tagged PDF provides markup for real content (structure of documents) while ignoring artifacts such as page numbers. The aim is to embed logical structure for accessibility and repurposing of content.
 
Challenges in automated metadata extraction
As the PDF format conserves layout and design rather than logical document structure, automated extraction of even basic bibliographic metadata (title, publisher, authors, affiliations, …) is challenging. Humans can recognize the format of text from layout and overcome inconsistencies and vagueness from different layouts used by different publishers, but machine-based technology cannot. Machines cannot infer structure from design choices.
 
Numerous automated tools exist (details beyond the scope of this essay), using different approaches aiming for bulk processing without user interaction, high accuracy and high adaptivity (to diverse formatting layouts). But all tools are error-prone – note that 80% success means 20% failure! Ideally, metadata are stored within a PDF file – but this is rarely the case (and if so, not in a standardized way), hence full text has to be analyzed.
 
Additional challenges are due to
  • scanned documents (rather than born digital), requiring OCR (optical character recognition) for processing of text content
  • badly formed pdf’s (created by a multitude of software tools). Adobe Reader has a high tolerance for rendering invalid pdf files. Digital collections are very likely to contain badly formed pdf files, but consequences for long-term preservation and future access are unclear.
  • the multitude of different pdf versions over the years
 
Recommendations
  • Provide PDF files in PDF/A format and as tagged PDF. Both has to be intentionally selected (Save as PDF -> Options). Note that an existing generic PDF file cannot be sensibly converted to PDF/A because relevant information has been lost during conversion of a source file to PDF.
  • Provide metadata within a PDF file. Ideally or rather hypothetically, this should be done in a standardized way – however, currently standards do not exist.
  • If possible, provide the original format(s) and/or a machine-readable format (e.g. XML) along with a PDF file.
 
“PDF/A is not a preservation solution on its own: rather it needs to integrate with other components of a wider preservation strategy” [Digital Preservation Coalition UK]
